questions.question_text: An engineer is designing a data center that uses FCIP. How is QoS configured in this environment?

choices.B: A separate DSCP value must be configured for all FCIP VSAN traffic.
choices.C: A separate DSCP value and priority queuing must be configured for all FCIP traffic.
choices.D: Two separate DSCP values must be configured, one of all of the FCIP frames in the control TCP connection and another for all of the FCIP frames in the data connection.
choices.A: A separate DSCP value and CoPP must be configured for all FCIP traffic and another for all of the FCIP in the data connection.

discussion.content: Two separate DSCP values must be configured, one for control frames another one for data frames.

choices.C: Configure the port channel to enable individual buffer-to-buffer credits.
choices.E: Configure the flow control for the FC to use R_RDY.
choices.A: Configure ER_RDY to allow splitting of each ISL between switches into separate virtual links.
choices.B: Use the port-monitor command to detect slow drain devices.
choices.D: Configure the port monitor to allow categorization of a specific device as slow.

questions.question_text: Which two methods mitigate congestion in a SAN network? (Choose two.)

comments.content: Also, option B doesn't actually mitigate anything it just "monitors" the problem.

discussion.content:
I would say A and D

- Extended Receiver Ready—This feature allows each ISL between supporting switches to be split into four separate virtual links, with each virtual link assigned its own buffer-to-buffer credits. Virtual link 0 used to carry control traffic, virtual link 1 is used to carry high-priority traffic, virtual link 2 is used to carry slow devices, and virtual link 3 is used to carry normal traffic.

- Congestion Isolation—This feature allows devices to be categorized as slow by either configuration command or by port monitor.

- Port monitor portguard action for Congestion Isolation—Port monitor has a new portguard option to allow the categorization of a device as slow so that it can have all traffic flowing to the device routed to the slow virtual link.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/mds9000/sw/8_x/config/interfaces/cisco_mds9000_interfaces_config_guide_8x/congestion_avoidance_isolation.html

discussion.content:
I think : 
Zone : Used to logically separate a SAN Fabric
ISL : must be considered [...] Aversubscription Ratio
Fabric Login : virtualization
VSAN : considered when implementing access control

Zone separate a SAN fabric in small end-point group
VSAN could be used to separate administration access

questions.question_text: Which two automation requirements can be met by using Puppet? (Choose two.)

choices.B: Enable clients to pull changes to configuration files.
choices.E: Enable one-off infrastructure changes to be performed manually.
choices.A: Push configuration updates immediately to servers.
choices.D: Provide support for writing new modules in Python.
choices.C: Enable clients to pull changes without installing an agent.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
Will also go A and B. FonT says A is wrong, but the referenced link in the Answer literally says you can provision servers and that would be a push.

Answers should be B. E.
because : 
- A is wrong : no push in puppet
- B is OK
- C is wrong, you need an agent with puppet
- D is wrong, no support from cisco and it's not python language
- E I don't know, but the best choice

vPC provides the following technical benefits:
● Eliminates Spanning Tree Protocol (STP) blocked ports
● Uses all available uplink bandwidth
● Allows dual-homed servers to operate in active-active mode
● Provides fast convergence upon link or device failure
● Offers dual active/active default gateways for servers vPC also leverages native split horizon/loop management provided by port-channeling technology: a packet entering a port-channel cannot immediately exit that same port-channel.

questions.question_text: What are two advantages of using Cisco vPC over traditional access layer designs? (Choose two.)
